title: Is disk distance proportional to x-squared

content.question:

Students use a force sensor to push a disk of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> across a horizontal table. The force sensor pushes the disk with a force of constant magnitude over a short time interval. The magnitude of the force and the duration of the time interval can be set by the students. After being pushed by the sensor, the disk first slides along a surface with negligible friction and then enters a rough section where friction is not negligible, as shown above.

This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

Students use a force sensor to push a disk of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> across a horizontal table. The force sensor pushes the disk with a force of constant magnitude over a short time interval. The magnitude of the force and the duration of the time interval can be set by the students. After being pushed by the sensor, the disk first slides along a surface with negligible friction and then enters a rough section where friction is not negligible, as shown above.

The students perform two trials in which the magnitude of the force exerted by the force sensor and the time interval are different. They create the graphs of force as a function of time shown below. The disk enters the rough surface in each trial after <math alttext="t equals 0.5 second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>s</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) In which of the two trials, if either, is the speed of the disk the greatest at time 0.5 seconds? Explain your reasoning.

(b) In both trials, the disk comes to rest in the rough section before reaching the edge of the table. In which trial, if either, does the disk travel a greater distance in the rough section? Explain your reasoning.

(c) The students repeat Trial 1 with a disk that is made from the same material as the original disk but that is more massive. The same force is exerted on the more massive disk over the same time interval as in Trial 1. Would the distance traveled in the rough section by the more massive disk be greater than, less than, or the same as the distance traveled by the original disk in Trial 1? Explain your reasoning.

Students derive the following equation, which may or may not be correct, to describe the distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> traveled by the original disk on the rough section: <math alttext="D equals the fraction with numerator, F squared times t squared, and denominator, 2 mu, times m times g, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the force exerted by the sensor, <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the time that the disk is in contact with the sensor, <math alttext="mu" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu) is the coefficient of kinetic friction, and <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the mass of the disk.
(d) Without algebraic manipulation of equations or attempting to derive this equation, indicate whether the above equation is consistent with your answer in part (b). Explain your reasoning.

A student measures the distance <math alttext="x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that the disk travels while in contact with the force sensor in Trial 1. The disk then travels a distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> along the rough section. The student claims that if the same force is exerted on the disk for a distance <math alttext="2 x sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the disk would travel a distance <math alttext="2 D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the rough section.
(e) Is the above claim correct or incorrect? Justify your answer without citing or manipulating equations.

The student finds the following equation on the Internet describing the relationship between the distance <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> the disk is pushed and the distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> it slides in the rough section: <math alttext="D equals C times the fraction with numerator, F times x squared, and denominator, mu, times m times g, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>C</mi><mfrac><mrow><mi>F</mi><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a constant with appropriate units.
(f) Indicate whether or not the equation above is consistent with your statement in part (e) relating <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain your reasoning.
